newContent.title: 2026 Priorities & Predictions Report
keyFindings: 68% of CHROs prioritize AI-related workforce initiatives as top concern
80% of Future of Work leaders focused on redesigning work for AI
Only 12% of organizations mature in skills-based workforce models
Four predictions: AI-driven layoffs as strategic lever, skills as OS of work, digital work twins, dynamic workforce design

newContent.title: 4 Priorities for Future of Work Leaders in 2026
keyFindings: Redesigning work due to AI (80%) is top priority
Reimagining enterprise organization design (70%) - shift from rigid job-based hierarchies to project/task-based models
Organizations moving from 'static structures to living systems of work'
Internal talent marketplaces enabling fluid deployment across projects

newContent.title: 4 Priorities for CHROs in 2026
keyFindings: HR operating model evolution: HR Business Partners becoming 'performance enablers', Centers of Expertise becoming 'enterprise intelligence architects', Shared Services becoming 'experience engines powered by AI'
Shift from three-pillar HR model to 'fluid, intelligence-driven ecosystem'
Agentic AI governance: 'treat AI agents like interns - capable fast learners requiring oversight, context, and clear boundaries'
Work deconstruction approach: deconstructing roles into tasks to clarify AI augmentation vs human judgment

newContent.title: 4 Priorities for Chief Learning & Talent Officers in 2026
keyFindings: 59% of CLTOs focused on enterprise-wide upskilling
43% implementing AI technology/services for adaptive learning
High-performers 4x more likely to have strong learning cultures
Shift to embedding development 'into the flow of work' rather than formal programs

structuralFindings.description: Organizations deconstructing roles into tasks, determining which work should be done by humans vs AI, redeploying capacity toward higher-value outcomes
Shift from rigid job-based hierarchies to project/task-based models with internal talent marketplaces enabling fluid talent deployment
Organizations treating AI agents like interns - capable fast learners requiring oversight, context, and clear boundaries ('intern year' for agentic AI)
Three-pillar HR model evolving to intelligence-driven ecosystem: HRBPs as performance enablers, CoEs as intelligence architects, Shared Services as AI-powered experience engines

quotableInsight: The architecture of work itself is being rewritten. - Kevin Oakes, i4cp Founder
summary: First scan of i4cp. Their 2026 Priorities Report represents comprehensive survey of CHROs and HR executives on AI-driven workforce transformation. Key findings: 80% of Future of Work leaders prioritizing work redesign for AI, 70% reimagining org design from job-based to task-based models, 68% of CHROs focused on AI workforce initiatives. Notable structural mechanisms include work deconstruction (breaking roles into tasks for AI/human allocation), internal talent marketplaces, and treating agentic AI like 'interns requiring supervision'. The HR function itself is evolving from three-pillar model to 'intelligence-driven ecosystem.' Only 12% of orgs mature in skills-based models despite being seen as future direction.
crossReferences: Potentially relevant to existing specimens implementing task-based work models or internal talent marketplaces
